item.title: Isaiah 1
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 1

1 Visions Isaiah Ben-Amoz Saw About Judah and Jerusalem During the Reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz, and Hezekiah, Kings of Judah Rebellious Judah

2 Listen, earth and sky, Yahveh says, “I brought up sons, but they’ve rebelled.

3 An ox knows its owner, and a donkey recognizes its owner’s manger, but Israel doesn’t know me; my people don’t recognize that I’m the One who provided for them."

item.title: Isaiah 2
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 2

1 A Message Isaiah Ben-Amoz Saw About Judah and Jerusalem

2 In the last days, the mountain where Yahveh’s Temple is, will become the tallest mountain; it will rise above the hills, and nations everywhere will stream into it.

3 Many nationalities will say, “Let’s go up to Yahveh’s mountain, to the Temple of Jacob’s God, so he can teach us his ways and we can follow his paths,” because the Law will go out from Zion, Yahveh’s message from Jerusalem.

item.title: Isaiah 3
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 3

1 The Lord Yahveh of Hosts will remove food and water from Judah and Jerusalem,

2 strong men and soldiers, judges and prophets, fortunetellers and elders,

3 captains of 50 and their men, advisors, expert magicians, and skilled astrologers. 4"I’ll make boys their officials, babies their rulers;

5 people will oppress one another, neighbor against neighbor; youths will insult elders; inferiors will be rude to honorable citizens."

item.title: Isaiah 4
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 4

1 At that time, seven widows will grab hold of one man and say, “We’ll provide our own food and clothes. Just let us take your name so we won’t be old maids!"

2 But at that time, Yahveh’s branch will be beautiful and glorious. What the ground produces will be the pride and joy of Israel’s survivors. 3The remnant in Zion and Jerusalem will be holy, everybody that’s in his record books for living there. 4When Yahveh has washed the grime off of Zion’s inhabitants and cleaned up the bloodstains in Jerusalem by the spirit of judgment and burning, 5then he’ll create over Mount Zion and its assemblies a cloud of smoke during the day, a bright blazing fire at night, and a canopy above the glory. 6It’ll be shade from daytime heat and shelter from storms and rain. The Song of the Vineyard

item.title: Isaiah 5
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 5

1 For the one I love, let me sing a song about his vineyard: The one I love had a vineyard on a fertile hill.

2 He spaded up the ground, picked up the rocks, and planted the best grapevines in it; he built a tower there and hewed out a stone wine vat; he expected it to produce good grapes, but it produced wild ones. 3"People in Judah and Jerusalem, judge between me and my vineyard.

item.title: Isaiah 6
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 6

1 The year King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord sitting on a high throne, and his train filled the Temple. 2Seraphs hovered above him, each with six wings: two covered their faces, two covered their feet, and with two they flew. 3One shouted to the other, “Holy, Holy, Holy is Yahveh of Hosts; the whole world is full of his glory."

4 The thresholds shook when he shouted, and smoke filled the Temple. 5I said, “I’m doomed! I’m lost, a man with unclean lips living among people with unclean lips, and I’ve seen the King, Yahveh of Hosts!"

item.title: Isaiah 7
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 7

1 At the time of Ahaz Ben-Jotham Ben-Uzziah, king of Judah, Rezin, king of Syria, and Pekah Ben-Remaliah, king of Israel, attacked Jerusalem but couldn’t take it. 2When the news reached Judah’s royal court that Syria was in league with Ephraim, their hearts sank, and they shook like trees in the wind.

3 Yahveh said to Isaiah, “Take your son Shear-jashub [A remnant will return] and go meet Ahaz at the end of the aqueduct that supplies the Upper Pool on the road to the Fuller’s Field. 4-6Tell him not to worry about Rezin and Remaliah’s son. He doesn’t need to be afraid or fainthearted over the fierce anger of those two smoldering sticks. True, they’re plotting to attack Judah and install Tabeel as king there. 7-9But that’s not going to happen. Syria’s headquarters is in Damascus, led by Rezin; Ephraim’s headquarters is in Samaria, led by Remaliah. Just trust me, and I’ll make you outlast them. In 65 years, Ephraim will be shattered, no longer a people."

item.title: Isaiah 8
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 8

1 Then Yahveh told me, “Take a large tablet and etch on it in standard letters ‘Maher-shalal-hash-baz’ [quick to the plunder, swift to the spoil].” 2I got reputable men to witness it: Uriah the priest and Zechariah Ben-Jeberechiah. 3So I had relations with my wife the prophetess, and she had a son. Yahveh told me, “Name him Maher-shalal-hash-baz, 4because before he knows how to say ‘daddy’ or ‘mommy,’ the king of Assyria will ‘carry away the wealth’ in Damascus and ’the spoil’ in Samaria."

item.title: Isaiah 9
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 9

1 But there won’t be any more darkness for those who have been in distress. In earlier times, God didn’t give much prominence to the territory of Zebulun and Naphtali, but at a future time he’ll make it glorious along the road from the Jordan along the Sea of Galilee, Galilee of the Gentiles.

2 Those who walk in deep darkness will see a bright light; it will shine on people that live in a dark land.

item.title: Isaiah 10
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 10

1 Misfortune awaits judges that enact unfair laws and render illegal verdicts,

2 who deprive the needy of justice and rob the poor of their rights so they can make widows their spoil and orphans their plunder.

3 What are you going to do when punishment arrives, when devastation comes from far off? Who will you run to for help? Where will you hide your wealth?

4 There’ll be nothing left for you but to crouch among the captives or fall among the slain. Even then, his anger won’t be spent; his fist will still be raised. Judgment Against Assyria 5"Misfortune awaits Assyria, the club my anger is using, the staff I’ve loaded with my indignation.

item.title: Isaiah 11
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 11

1 A sapling will grow out of Jesse’s stump; a branch from his roots will bear fruit.

2 Yahveh’s spirit will rest on him, the spirit of wisdom and insight, counsel and strength, knowledge and respect for Yahveh.

3 He’ll delight in respecting Yahveh; he won’t judge by appearances or render verdicts based on hearsay.

4 He’ll judge the poor justly and decide for the meek fairly. He’ll shake the ground with the force of his words and blow the sinful away with his breath.

item.title: Isaiah 12
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 12

1 At that time, you’ll say, “Thank you, Yahveh; though you were angry with me, you turned your anger away and reassured me.

2 You’re my salvation; I’ll trust you and not be afraid, because you’re my strength and song."

3 So I’ll draw water with joy from the wells of salvation

4 and say, “Thank Yahveh, call on him; tell everyone what he’s done; tell them his name is Honored.

item.title: Isaiah 13
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 13

1 Oracle About Babylon That Isaiah Ben-Amoz Saw 2"Hoist a signal flag on a bare hilltop; call out an army and signal them to attack the mansions of the nobles.

3 I’ve commanded my consecrated ones and strong men to carry out my anger."

4 There’s noise in the mountains like a large army, the uproar of gathered kingdoms! Yahveh of Hosts is mustering an army for war.

item.title: Isaiah 14
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 14

1 When Yahveh will have mercy on Jacob, choose Israel again, and settle them in their own land, foreigners will join Jacob’s house. 2The nations will help bring them home. Israel will possess them as an inheritance in Yahveh’s land, as male and female servants. They’ll capture their captors and rule their rulers. 3When Yahveh gives them relief from their pain, turmoil, and harsh slavery, 4they’ll taunt the king of Babylon: “How the big bully has ceased bullying and stopped his insolence!

item.title: Isaiah 15
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 15

1 Oracle About Moab Moab will be ruined because Ar and Kir will be wiped out overnight.

2 The people of Dibon will go up to their temple and high places to weep. Moab will mourn over Nebo and Medeba; everyone’s head will be bald, and their beard shaved off.

3 They’ll put on burlap in the streets and squares and on the housetops. Everyone will be wailing, melting in tears.

item.title: Isaiah 16
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 16

1 Send tribute lambs to the ruler of the land, from Sela through the desert to Mount Zion.

2 At the Arnon fords the women of Moab will be left fluttering like birds or homeless nestlings. 3"Give us advice, grant us justice; cast your shadow on us like night at noon to hide us outcasts; don’t betray us fugitives.

4 Let our refugees from Moab stay among you; hide us from the destroyer." When oppression and destruction end and raiders have left the land, God will establish one of David’s descendants as king;

item.title: Isaiah 17
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 17

1 Oracle About Damascus “Damascus will stop being a city, and become a pile of ruins.

2 The villages around Aroer will be deserted; flocks will bed down in them, with no one to chase them away.

3 Fortified towns will disappear from Ephraim, sovereignty from Damascus and the remnant from Syria; they’ll be like Israel’s departed glory,” Yahveh of hosts says. 4"At that time, Jacob’s glory will fade; his robust body will grow frail.

item.title: Isaiah 18
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 18

1 Ah, land of fluttering wings, land beyond the headwaters of the Nile in Nubia,

2 that sends envoys by sea in papyrus boats— go swiftly, ambassadors, to a nation tall and smooth, a people feared far and wide, a powerful, oppressive nation crisscrossed by rivers.

3 All of you that live in the world, look when I raise the signal on the mountains, listen when I blow the ram’s horn,

item.title: Isaiah 19
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 19

1 Oracle About Egypt Yahveh is riding a swift cloud to Egypt; Egypt’s idols tremble in his presence; the Egyptians’ hearts melt. 2"I’ll pit the Egyptians against one another, brother against brother, neighbor against neighbor; city against city, district against district.

3 They’ll be demoralized; I’ll confuse their strategy so they’ll resort to their idols and spirits of the dead, to mediums and spiritists.

4 I’ll deliver them to a cruel master; a powerful king will rule them," the Lord Yahveh of Hosts says.

item.title: Isaiah 20
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 20

1 Sargon, king of Assyria, sent his general to attack Ashdod. 2That year Yahveh spoke through Isaiah Ben-Amoz, “Take the burlap off your waist and remove your sandals.” So he went around naked and barefoot. 3Yahveh said, “My servant Isaiah has gone naked and barefoot for three years as an omen to Egypt and Nubia. 4The king of Assyria will lead captives away from there, young and old, naked and barefoot with their butts showing, to Egypt’s humiliation. 5People will be disgraced and disappointed by Nubia their hope and Egypt their pride. 6The people along the coast will say, ‘Look at what’s happened to them! How can we escape who fled there for protection from the king of Assyria?!’"

item.title: Isaiah 21
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 21

1 Oracle About the Sandy Wastes Beside the Sea Like a haboob sweeping in from the Negev, catastrophe will sweep in through the desert from a terrible land.

2 I see a harsh vision: plunderers plundering; destroyers destroying. Go on, Elam; lay siege, Media. I’m going to put an end to the groaning Babylon’s caused.

3 My body’s in agony; pangs have seized me like a woman in labor. I’m so faint I can’t hear, so scared I can’t see.

item.title: Isaiah 22
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 22

1 Oracle About the Valley of Vision What’s the matter with you? Why are you all running up to the housetops?

2 You noisy, exuberant city in an uproar, your dead weren’t slain in battle, but by famine and disease.

3 Your rulers all fled together and were captured without resistance; your people were discovered and taken captive too, though they’d tried to escape.

4 So I said, “Leave me alone to weep bitterly; don’t try to comfort me about the destruction of my people."

item.title: Isaiah 23
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 23

1 Oracle About Tyre Wail, you merchant ships of Tarshish, because Tyre’s destroyed without home or harbor, just like the rumor you heard all the way over at Cyprus.

2 Be quiet, you people on the coast, merchants of Sidon; your traders crossed the sea

3 and sailed on many bodies of water. Grain from the Nile, harvest from the Shihor was your revenue; you were the international marketplace.

item.title: Isaiah 24
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 24

1 Yahveh is laying the earth waste, defacing its surface, scattering its residents. 2People and priests, servants and masters, maids and mistresses, buyers and sellers, lenders and borrowers, creditors and debtors—everyone will be affected. 3The earth will be completely despoiled because Yahveh said so. 4The earth withers, and its people waste away, even its high-ranking ones, 5because they’ve polluted it by sinning against God’s laws, statutes, and everlasting covenant. 6So a curse devastates the earth, and its people have to pay for their guilt. They’re burned; there aren’t many left.

item.title: Isaiah 25
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 25

1 Yahveh, you’re my God. I’ll honor and thank you for doing the wonderful things you planned long ago.

2 You’ve reduced fortified towns to ruble; the foreigners’ palaces will never be rebuilt.

3 So strong people will honor you; towns in ruthless nations will come to revere you,

4 because you’ve defended the helpless and needy in their despair; you’re a shelter from the storm and a shade from heat, because the breath of ruthless people is like a storm beating on a wall

item.title: Isaiah 26
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 26

1 At that time, they’ll sing a song in Judah: We have an impregnable city; it’s set up with secure walls and ramparts.

2 Open the gates so a good nation can enter, one that stays faithful.

3 You keep steadfast minds in perfect peace because they trust in you.

4 Trust in Yahveh forever because in him we have an everlasting Rock.

5 He brings down low the ones that live up high in their “safe city”; he throws it to the ground.

item.title: Isaiah 27
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 27

1 At that time, Yahveh will punish Leviathan with his fierce, big strong sword, Leviathan the swift, slithering snake. He’ll kill the dragon that’s in the sea.

2 Then, “There’ll be a delightful vineyard to sing about!

3 I, Yahveh, will be its keeper; I’ll water it constantly and guard it day and night so no one harms it.

4 I won’t be angry anymore. If anybody gives me briars and thorns in battle, I’ll trample and burn them completely

item.title: Isaiah 28
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 28

1 Misfortune awaits the proud crown of Ephraim’s drunks, the fading flower of its glorious beauty, Samaria, that’s at the head of the fertile valley of those drunk with wine.

2 Yahveh has a strong and powerful military agent; he’ll throw Samaria down on the ground like a hail storm, destructive gale, overwhelming flood.

3 The proud crown of Ephraim’s drunks will get tramped on;

4 the fading flower of its glorious beauty that’s at the head of the fertile valley, will be like the first-ripe fig of summer: as soon as it’s seen, it’s picked and eaten.

item.title: Isaiah 29
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 29

1 Misfortune awaits you, Ariel, city where David camped! Year after year, you observe the festivals on schedule.

2 Yet I’ll bring disaster on you, Ariel; you’ll lament and mourn; you’ll be to me what Ariel means [blood-covered altar].

3 I’ll camp against you all the way around and set up siege works and battle towers.

4 You’ll be brought low; you’ll speak from the ground where you lie prostrate; you’ll speak like a spirit conjured up from the dirt, like a whisper from the grave. 5"But suddenly your many enemies will be like fine dust blown away, ruthless attackers like chaff gone with a gust of wind.

item.title: Isaiah 30
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 30

1 Yahveh says, “Misfortune awaits rebellious children that carry out plans, but not mine, that make alliances, but not by my Spirit, and thereby pile sin on top of error;

2 children that go down to Egypt to get help instead of consulting me, to take refuge in Pharaoh’s safety, to look for shelter under Egypt’s shadow.

3 The safety that comes from Pharaoh will humiliate them; the shelter under Egypt’s shadow will disgrace them.

item.title: Isaiah 31
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 31

1 Misfortune lies ahead for those who go down to Egypt for help, who rely on horses, that trust in chariots because they are many and in horsemen because they are strong, instead of looking to the Holy One of Israel, instead of consulting Yahveh!

2 He’s wise and brings disaster and doesn’t take back what he says; he rises up at the sinful and their helpers.

item.title: Isaiah 32
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 32

1 A righteous king is coming; his princes will rule honestly.

2 Each will provide a refuge from the wind, a shelter from the storm, a stream of water in the desert, the shade of a big tree in parched land.

3 Then the seeing will perceive; the hearing will listen.

4 The rash will use good judgment; stuttering tongues will speak fluently.

5 Fools won’t be called noble anymore; rogues won’t be considered generous;

item.title: Isaiah 33
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 33

1 Misfortune awaits you, destroyers who haven’t been destroyed yourselves; misfortune awaits you, treacherous people that others haven’t treated treacherously. As soon as you’re done destroying, you’ll be destroyed; as soon as you’ve finished your treachery, others will deal treacherously with you.

2 Yahveh, be gracious to us; we’ve waited for you; be our strength each morning, our deliverer when trouble comes.

3 Let people run from the turmoil you bring; let nations scatter when you threaten.

item.title: Isaiah 34
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 34

1 Come close, nations, and listen! world and everything in it, pay attention.

2 Yahveh is furious with the nations and their armies; he’ll destroy them and deliver them to slaughter.

3 Their slain will be thrown out; their corpses will reek; their blood will soak the hillsides.

4 The stars will fade out; the sky will roll up like a scroll. it’ll wither away like leaves on a grapevine or fig tree. 5"My sword has drunk its fill in the sky; it will come down in condemnation on Edom, a nation I’ve devoted to complete destruction.

item.title: Isaiah 35
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 35

1 The desert wilderness will be happy; the Arabah will blossom profusely with crocuses, and sing and celebrate. It will be as glorious as Lebanon, as majestic as Carmel and Sharon. They’ll see the glory of Yahveh, the majesty of our God.

3 Strengthen feeble hands; steady weak knees.

4 Say to those with pounding hearts, “Be strong and not afraid; your God will avenge you and save you."

item.title: Isaiah 36
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 36

1 In the fourteenth year of King Hezekiah, Sennacherib king of Assyria attacked the fortified towns in Judah and took them. 2He sent the Rabshakeh from Lachish to Jerusalem with a large army. They took position by the aqueduct to the upper pool on the road to the Fuller’s Field. 3Eliakim Ben-Hilkiah, the palace administrator; Shebna, the court secretary; and Joah Ben-Asaph, the royal historian, went out to meet them.

item.title: Isaiah 37
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 37

1 When Hezekiah heard it, he tore his clothes, put on burlap, and went to the Temple. 2He sent Eliakim, Shebna, and the senior priests to the prophet Isaiah. 3They went to him and said, “Hezekiah says, ‘This is a distressing, discouraging, dejecting day. Babies have come due, but there’s no strength to deliver them. 4Maybe Yahveh your God has heard the Rabshakeh that the king of Assyria sent to mock the living God. Maybe he’ll reprove him for it. Pray for the remnant that’s left.’” [5]

item.title: Isaiah 38
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 38

1 Around that time, Hezekiah got deathly ill, and Isaiah came to tell him, “Yahveh says to set your house in order; you’re going to die."

2 Hezekiah turned to the wall and prayed, 3"Yahwh, please remember how I’ve followed you honestly with all my heart and done what you consider good.” He cried bitterly.

4 Then a message from Yahveh came to Isaiah: 5"Go back and tell Hezekiah that Yahveh God of your ancestor David says, ‘I’ve heard your prayer and seen your tears. I’ll give you 15 more years to live 6and deliver you and this city from the king of Assyria. 7This is the sign that I’ll do what I’ve said: 8I’ll make the shadow on Ahaz’s stairway go back up 10 steps.’" So it went back up 10 steps.

item.title: Isaiah 39
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 39

1 Soon after this, Merodach-baladan Ben-Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a present to Hezekiah because he’d heard he’d been sick and had recovered. 2That pleased Hezekiah, and he showed the ambassadors everything in his treasure house, the silver and gold, the spices and precious oil, his whole armory, and everything in his royal treasuries. There wasn’t anything in his palace or kingdom that he didn’t show them.

item.title: Isaiah 40
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 40

1 Comfort, comfort my people," your God says. 2"Speak graciously to Jerusalem; tell it that its warfare’s over, its iniquity’s removed, it’s received from Yahveh double for its sins."

3 A voice is calling, “Build a road for Yahveh in the desert; make a smooth highway for our God.

4 Fill every pothole, level off every bump and high spot. Smooth the rough ground and make rugged terrain like a wide valley.

item.title: Isaiah 41
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 41

1 Lands beyond the sea, come to order and listen; prepare your case; step forward and present it; your case is next on the docket.

2 Who has stirred up the king in the east that he rightly called to his service, who delivers up nations and subdues kings; who makes them like dust with his sword, like wind-driven chaff with his bow;

3 who chases them away and passes along safely on paths he hasn’t walked before?

item.title: Isaiah 42
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 42

1 My Servant that I uphold, my Chosen One I delight in, I’ve put my Spirit on him; he’ll bring righteousness to the Gentiles.

2 He won’t holler or be boisterous; he won’t make a racket in the streets.

3 He won’t break a bruised reed or put out a flickering wick; he’ll faithfully render justice.

4 He won’t falter or lose heart; he’ll establish justice on earth; distant lands will rely on his instruction."

item.title: Isaiah 43
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 43

1 But this is what Yahveh your creator says, Jacob, the One that formed you, Israel, “You don’t need to be afraid, because I’ve redeemed you and called you by name. You’re mine!

2 When you pass through the sea, I’m with you; when you cross rivers, they won’t flood over you; when you walk through fire, the flame won’t burn you;

3 because I’m Yahveh your God, the Holy One of Israel, your Savior. I’ve given Egypt to ransom you, Nubia and Seba in exchange for you.

item.title: Isaiah 44
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 44

1 But listen now, Jacob my servant, Israel my chosen one.

2 This is what Yahveh says who created you and formed you from the womb, who will help you: ‘Don’t be afraid, Jacob my servant, Jeshurun my chosen one.

3 As I’ll pour out water on thirsty ground to make streams on desert land, I’ll also pour out my Spirit on your offspring and bless your descendants;

item.title: Isaiah 45
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 45

1 This is what Yahveh says to Cyrus his anointed whose right hand he’ll empower to subdue nations and dethrone kings, to open fortress gates so they won’t be shut: 2"I’ll go ahead of you to level out the mountains, shatter bronze gates, and cut through their iron bars.

3 I’ll give you treasures stored in the dark and wealth hidden in secret places, so you’ll know it’s me, Yahveh God of Israel, who calls you by name.

item.title: Isaiah 46
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 46

1 Bel bows down, Nebo stoops over; their images, loaded on beasts of burden and livestock, are too heavy for their tired animals to bear.

2 The idols themselves are stooped over; their owners are bowed down too; the people couldn’t keep the burden from going into captivity with them. 3"Listen to me, House of Jacob, remnant of Israel, you that I’ve carried from birth,

4 till your graying years I’ll do the same; I’ve made you, and I’ll take care of you, carry you along, and save you. 5"What can you compare me with? Who’s my equal?

item.title: Isaiah 47
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 47

1 Come sit in the dirt, virgin daughter of Babylon. Sit on the ground without a throne; you won’t be treated honorably anymore.

2 Grind meal with heavy millstones; take off your veil, strip off your skirt, uncover your legs and cross the rivers.

3 Your nakedness will show; your shame will be exposed; in my revenge I won’t spare you or anybody else."

4 Our Redeemer is the Holy One of Israel; Yahveh of Hosts is his name. 5"Sit silently in the dark, daughter of Babylon; you won’t be called the queen of kingdoms anymore.

item.title: Isaiah 48
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 48

1 Listen to this, Jacob called ‘Israel,’ that came from Judah’s family, that swear by Yahveh and invoke Israel’s God, but not sincerely and rightly,

2 that call yourself The Holy City and depend on Yahveh of Hosts:

3 long ago, I told you what was going to happen; all at once it has; my prediction has come true.

4 I know how stubborn you are, that your neck is as stiff as iron, and your head is as hard as bronze.

item.title: Isaiah 49
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 49

1 Listen, far off lands; pay attention, distant nations. Yahveh called me before I was born; he named me inside my mother’s body.

2 He made my mouth like a sharp sword and hid me under his hand; he made a polished arrow out of me and put me in his quiver.

3 He told me, “You’re my servant, Israel; I’ll demonstrate my glory in you."

4 But I replied, “I haven’t really accomplished anything; I’ve just worn myself out for nothing; yet surely my just due is in Yahveh’s hands; I’ll have to trust him for my reward."

item.title: Isaiah 50
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 50

1 Yahveh says, “Did I put your mother away with divorce papers? Did I sell you as slaves to pay my debts? No, I sold you because of your transgressions and divorced your mother for her sins.

2 When I came, why wasn’t anybody home? When I knocked, why didn’t anyone answer the door? Am I too poor to pay a ransom; don’t I have the strength to rescue? I can dry up the sea with a word, make rivers empty and the fish in them die and stink.

item.title: Isaiah 51
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 51

1 Listen to me, you that want to be good, that look to Yahveh, the Rock you were hewn from, the quarry you came from.

2 Look to Abraham your ancestor, to Sarah who bore you in pain; he was just one man when I called him; then I blessed him and multiplied him."

3 Indeed, Yahveh will comfort Zion again and have mercy on its desolate places; he’ll make its wilderness like Eden, its desert like Yahveh’s orchard. Joy and happiness will be there, thanksgiving and songs. 4"Listen, my people; pay attention, my nation, because my law will go out from me; my justice will shine like a light for the nations, to distant lands that wait for me.

item.title: Isaiah 52
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 52

1 Wake up, wake up; dress yourself with strength, Zion; put on your beautiful clothes, Jerusalem the holy city; defiled, godless people won’t invade you anymore.

2 Get up, shake off the dust, captive Jerusalem; take the chains off your neck, resident in Zion,

3 because Yahveh says: “You were sold for nothing; you’ll be redeemed without money.

4 In the beginning my people went down to Egypt to live; now the Assyrians oppress them for no reason.

item.title: Isaiah 53
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 53

1 Who has believed our message? Who has Yahveh shown his arm to? He grew up before Yahveh like a tender sprout, like a shoot out of parched ground.

2 He wasn’t particularly handsome or noble to draw our attention to him or have the looks that would attract us to him.

3 People despised and abandoned him, a pained man, acquainted with grief; like someone people look the other way from, we looked down on him and didn’t respect him.

item.title: Isaiah 54
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 54

1 Shout for joy, childless woman; break into joyful shouting and cry out, you that have never had birth pangs; because the woman that’s by herself will have more children than a married woman," Yahveh says. 2"Make a bigger space for your tent; stretch out its curtains—don’t hold back; lengthen your guy ropes and drive your pegs deeper.

3 You’ll spread out left and right; your descendants will live in the nations and resettle the ruined towns. 4"Don’t be afraid, you won’t be disgraced; don’t feel humiliated, you won’t feel ashamed. You’ll forget the shame of your youth; you won’t remember the disgrace of your widowhood;

item.title: Isaiah 55
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 55

1 Everyone that’s thirsty, come to the water; you that don’t have any money, come, buy, and eat; get wine and milk for free.

2 Why spend money on what’s not food, wages on what doesn’t satisfy?

3 Come and listen so you can live; I’ll make an everlasting covenant with you like the faithful mercies I showed David.

4 I’ve appointed him as a witness to the nations, a leader and commander for them.

item.title: Isaiah 56
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 56

1 Yahveh says, “Maintain righteousness and be godly because my salvation’s coming; my deliverance will arrive.

2 They are fortunate who do that, who hold onto it, who honor my Sabbath and don’t do anything sinful.

3 Foreigners that join themselves to Yahveh shouldn’t say, ‘He’ll surely make a difference between me and his people’; eunuchs shouldn’t say, ‘I’m a dead tree.’"

4 Yahveh says, “For eunuchs that keep my Sabbaths holy, choose to do what pleases me, and keep my covenant—

item.title: Isaiah 57
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 57

1 Good people perish and nobody notices; the devout disappear without anyone realizing it, because God removes good people out of harm’s way.

2 They who take the godly road go to peace and rest in their graves. Idolatrous Worship Condemned 3"But come here, you sons of sorcerers, you offspring of adulterers and prostitutes.

4 Who are you making fun of? Who are you mouthing off to? Who are you sticking out your tongue at? Aren’t you rebellious brats, lying cads

item.title: Isaiah 58
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 58

1 Shout; don’t hold back; raise your voice like a ram’s horn; tell my people their transgressions.

2 They look to me daily and seem to delight to know my ways, as if they’re a good nation that hasn’t left my ordinances; they ask for favorable verdicts and act like they delight in drawing near to me.

3 Then they wonder, ‘Why have we fasted, and you haven’t noticed? Why have we humbled ourselves, and you haven’t acknowledged it?’ It’s because you fast to get what you want (meanwhile overworking your workers)!

item.title: Isaiah 59
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 59

1 It’s not that Yahveh’s hand is not too weak to save or his ear too deaf to hear you call.

2 It’s your iniquities that have separated you from him; your sins have shut him off from you, so he ignores you.

3 You’ve defiled your hands with blood, your fingers with sin, your lips with lying, your tongues with gossip.

4 None of you brings just suits or argues cases honestly; you hide behind double talk and perjury; you conceive schemes and give birth to sin.

item.title: Isaiah 60
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 60

1 Arise, shine; your light has come; the glory of Yahveh has risen on you.

2 Darkness will cover the earth; thick blackness will blanket the nations; but Yahveh will shine on you; his glory will appear on you.

3 Nations will come to your light, kings to the brightness of your rising. 4"Look all around you; they’re all gathering home to you. Your little boys will come from a long way off; your girls will be carried in arms.

item.title: Isaiah 61
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 61

1 The Spirit of the Lord Yahveh is on me; he’s anointed me to bring good news to the downtrodden. He’s sent me to bandage up the brokenhearted, to liberate captives, to free prisoners,

2 to announce that this is the year Yahveh shows blessing, the day he sets things right, to comfort anyone that’s grieving,

3 to give to the sad in Zion a crown in place of ashes, the oil of happiness instead of mourning, the mantle of praise rather than a fainting spirit so they’ll be like Terebinths of Goodness Yahveh has planted to demonstrate his glory.

item.title: Isaiah 62
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 62

1 For Zion’s sake I’ll speak to God; for Jerusalem’s sake I won’t keep still, until your goodness glows brightly, and your salvation radiates like a burning torch;

2 so the nations can witness your goodness and kings can gaze at your glory. Yahveh himself will give you a new name.

3 You’ll be a beautiful crown in his hand, a royal diadem he holds up high.

item.title: Isaiah 63
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 63

1 Who is this that’s coming from Edom in crimson clothes from Bozrah, one majestic in attire and marching with such power? “The One that’s announcing vindication, that has the strength to save."

2 Why are your clothes stained red like those who tread out grapes? 3"Ineed, I’ve been treading in a winepress—alone; nobody from the nations could help me; so I tramped down my foes in my fury; their life blood spattered my garments and stained my clothes.

item.title: Isaiah 64
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 64

1 Oh that you’d open the sky and come down and the mountains would quake in your presence—

2 like a flame that burns brush and boils water— to show yourself to your adversaries so they’d tremble in your presence!

3 When you did awesome things we didn’t expect, you came down and the mountains quaked in your presence.

4 No one has ever heard of a God like you that acts on behalf of people that wait for him.

item.title: Isaiah 65
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 65

1 I let people look for me who weren’t asking about me; people that weren’t looking for me found me. I said, ‘I’m here! Over here!’ to people that didn’t call on me.

2 All day long I spread out my hands to a rebellious nation that follows its own ideas,

3 that continually angers me to my face by offering sacrifices to idols in sacred gardens and burning incense on pagan altars,

item.title: Isaiah 66
item.description:
Isaiah Chapter 66

1 Yahveh says, “Heaven is my throne; earth is my footstool; where are you going to build me a Temple to rest in?

2 I made all this; that’s why it’s here. But the ones I especially love are humble with a repentant spirit and respect what I say. 3"But for the ones who’ve chosen their own way and delight in detestable things, offering an ox will be like human sacrifice, sacrificing a lamb will be like breaking a dog’s neck, offering a grain offering will be like offering pig’s blood, burning incense will be like blessing an idol.
